Ch.1 : Mechanics Domain
How can we use wheels and axles to create a moving car that requires minimal
effort?
To make a car with wheels and axles that moves easily:
● Reduce friction: Use smooth materials, lubrication, and bearings. ● Bigger wheels: Larger wheels roll farther with each turn. ● Lighten up: A lighter car needs less force to move.
Do It :
You have three cars. Form a team of three and begin your race, paying attention
to how the wheels and design of each car impact its movement.
How to make the 1 car : st
We will need :
1) 4 bottle caps
2) Stick for the axels
3) Cardboard piece ( 5 x 10 )
4) Balloon and strew 5) Glue gun sticks and glue gun

Steps :
1) Add the bottle caps to the sticks to make the wheels and axels
2) Glue the wheels and axels to the cardboard piece
3) Blow up a balloon and stick the strew to it 4) Stick it to the cardboard
Now you will observe
Car 1 :
● Wheels: Small, hard (likely plastic cap ) – inefficient rolling, especially on uneven surfaces.
● Design: Simple, lightweight frame; high center of gravity (balloon). ● Movement: Slow, unstable, prone to tipping (especially during turns/on bumps) due to
high center of gravity and friction from small wheels.
Car 2 :
● Wheels: rubber tires – better grip and smoother rolling. ● Design: Smooth to the ground – reduced air resistance and improved high-speed stability. ● Movement: Likely fastest and most stable; efficient movement and good handling.
Car 3 :
st ● Wheels: largest wheels, rubber tires. They look wider than the 1 car wheels, which might offer more stability. ● Design: Boxy shape, possibly heavier than the other two. The flat front will create more air resistance. ● Predicted Movement: Likely a middle ground between the other two. The wider wheels
should provide decent stability, but the boxy design will create more drag, slowing it down. It might be more robust than the 1 car though. st Watch it :

Materials:
● Laser-cut wooden base (design pre-made with motor mounts ) ● plastic wheels ● DC motors ● Wiring (for connecting motors to power) ● Power source (battery pack or power supply) ● Switch (to turn the motors on and off) ● Fasteners (screws, glue)
Tools:
● Laser cutting machine (for the base and potentially motor mounts)
Steps:
1. Design the Base (using CAD software): o Design the car base in CAD software. o Include:
▪ Precise axle holes (as before).

▪ Mounting points for the DC motors. These could be slots, holes for screws, or a designated area for gluing. ▪ Consider space for the battery pack and switch. 2. Design Motor Mounts (if needed): o If you're not directly mounting the motors to the base, design motor mounts in CAD software. These should securely hold the motors and allow for easy
attachment to the base. 3. Laser Cutting/3D Printing: o Laser cut the wooden base and any laser-cut motor mounts. o If you designed 3D printed mounts, print them now. 4. Connect Wheels to Motors: o This is where the power gets transferred! There are a few ways to do this: ▪ Direct Drive: Attach the wheels directly to the motor shafts (if the shafts
are the right size). ▪ Gears: Use gears to change the speed and torque of the motors. ▪ Couplers: Use flexible or rigid couplers to connect the motor shafts to the
axles. 5. Wiring: o Connect the motors to the power source (battery pack) using wires. o Include a switch in the circuit to control the power flow. o Make sure the wiring is neat and secure to prevent shorts or disconnections.
Key Considerations for Motorized Cars:
● Motor Selection: Choose motors with the appropriate voltage, RPM (revolutions per
minute), and torque (turning force) for your car's size and desired speed. ● Gear Ratios (if using gears): The gear ratio will affect the speed and torque of the car. A higher gear ratio will result in lower speed but higher torque, and vice versa. ● Power Source: Choose a battery pack or power supply that provides the correct voltage and current for the motors. ● Wiring and Connections: Ensure all wiring connections are secure and insulated to prevent shorts. ● Motor Control: For more advanced control, you could use a motor driver circuit or
microcontroller to control the speed and direction of the motors.
